description: SPM Knowledge Base Expansion Phase 2 - Reaching 1,000+ cards

cards.definition: A quota allocation methodology where targets originate from frontline sales reps and managers, aggregated upward to form company targets.
cards.whyItMatters: Increases quota buy-in and accuracy by incorporating field-level market intelligence.
cards.howItWorks: Reps submit territory-level forecasts → Managers validate and adjust → Roll-up to regional/company targets → Gap analysis vs. corporate objectives.
cards.example: Q1 bottoms-up: 50 reps submit $2M each = $100M. Corporate needs $120M. Gap of $20M distributed via stretch targets.

cards.definition: A quota allocation methodology where corporate targets are set first based on business objectives, then distributed downward to territories and reps.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures alignment with strategic business objectives and investor commitments.
cards.howItWorks: Board sets revenue target → Finance allocates by segment/region → Managers distribute to territories → Reps receive individual quotas.
cards.example: Board approves $500M target → 60% Enterprise, 40% Commercial → Regional splits based on TAM → Individual quotas by capacity model.
bestPractices: Use market data for fair distribution

cards.definition: A quota methodology combining tops-down targets with bottoms-up input to balance corporate objectives with field reality.
cards.whyItMatters: Achieves both strategic alignment and field buy-in, reducing quota disputes.
cards.howItWorks: Corporate sets preliminary targets → Field submits forecasts → Gap analysis meeting → Negotiated final quotas → Sign-off at all levels.
cards.example: Corporate wants $100M, field forecasts $85M. After review, agree on $95M with justified stretch assumptions.

cards.definition: A model showing expected sales performance over time, typically from hire through full productivity.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical for accurate capacity planning and new hire quota relief calculations.
cards.howItWorks: Month 1-3: 0-25% productivity → Month 4-6: 50-75% → Month 7-9: 75-90% → Month 10+: 100% productivity.
cards.example: Enterprise AE ramp: M1-M3 training (0%), M4-M6 ramping (50%), M7-M12 building (80%), Year 2+ fully productive (100%).

cards.definition: Forecasting and planning for expected sales rep turnover to maintain capacity coverage.
cards.whyItMatters: Unplanned attrition creates coverage gaps and missed targets; planning mitigates risk.
cards.howItWorks: Historical attrition rate × headcount = expected departures → Plan backfills → Factor ramp time → Net capacity model.
cards.example: 20% annual attrition on 100 reps = 20 departures. With 6-month ramp, need to hire 30+ to maintain capacity.

cards.definition: The organizational structure defining how sales resources are deployed against market opportunities.
cards.whyItMatters: Optimal coverage maximizes market penetration while controlling cost of sales.
cards.howItWorks: Segment market → Define buyer journey → Map required roles → Calculate capacity needed → Deploy resources.
cards.example: Enterprise: Named accounts with dedicated AEs. Mid-market: Territory-based. SMB: Inside sales with pooled accounts.

cards.definition: A coverage model separating new business acquisition (hunters) from existing customer growth (farmers).
cards.whyItMatters: Different skills required for acquisition vs. retention; specialization improves both.
cards.howItWorks: Hunters focus on net-new logos → Farmers manage installed base → Clear handoff at close → Separate comp plans.
cards.example: Hunter AE closes $500K new logo, hands to Farmer AM who grows to $2M ARR over 3 years.

cards.definition: A specialized sales role that supports primary account owners with domain expertise (technical, industry, product).
cards.whyItMatters: Provides deep expertise without requiring all AEs to be experts in everything.
cards.howItWorks: Primary AE owns account → Brings in overlay for specialized opportunities → Overlay supports, AE closes → Credit split per rules.
cards.example: Enterprise AE brings in Security Specialist for $200K security deal. Split: 100% AE quota credit, 50% overlay credit.

cards.definition: A higher commission rate applied to performance above a defined threshold, typically quota attainment.
cards.whyItMatters: Motivates over-performance and rewards top performers disproportionately.
cards.howItWorks: Base rate up to 100% quota → Accelerated rate above 100% → May have multiple tiers → Resets each period.
cards.example: 5% rate to 100%, 8% from 100-150%, 12% above 150%. On $1M quota: First $1M at 5%, next $500K at 8%, above at 12%.

cards.definition: A reduced commission rate applied to performance below a defined threshold, often used below quota floors.
cards.whyItMatters: Manages cost of low performers while maintaining some incentive to improve.
cards.howItWorks: Below floor: 0% or reduced rate → Floor to 100%: base rate → Above 100%: accelerated rate.
cards.example: 0% below 50% attainment, 3% from 50-100%, 6% above 100%. Creates strong motivation to reach 50% floor.

cards.definition: A maximum limit on commission earnings, typically expressed as percentage of target or absolute dollar amount.
cards.whyItMatters: Controls windfall risk but may demotivate high performers.
cards.howItWorks: Cap set at 2-3x target incentive → Earnings stop accruing at cap → May reset quarterly/annually.
cards.example: Target incentive $100K, cap at 3x = $300K max. Rep at 400% attainment earns $300K, not $400K.
bestPractices: Set high enough to be rarely hit

cards.definition: A minimum performance threshold below which no commission is earned.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures minimum acceptable performance before incentive payments begin.
cards.howItWorks: No payment below floor → At floor, payments begin → May be cumulative (catch-up) or non-cumulative.
cards.example: 50% floor: Rep at 40% earns $0. Rep at 60% earns on all 60% (cumulative) or just 10% above floor (non-cumulative).

cards.definition: A condition that must be met before commission payments begin or accelerators apply.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures balanced performance across multiple metrics, not just revenue.
cards.howItWorks: Primary metric payment contingent on gate metric → Gate typically a minimum threshold → May affect all or partial pay.
cards.example: Revenue commission gated on 80% customer retention. If retention at 75%, revenue commission reduced by 50%.

cards.definition: A structured table defining commission rates at different performance levels or for different products/scenarios.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables complex rate structures while maintaining clarity and consistency.
cards.howItWorks: Rows: Attainment bands → Columns: Product categories or deal types → Cell: Applicable rate.
cards.example: 80-100% attainment: Product A 5%, Product B 4%. 100-120%: Product A 7%, Product B 5.5%.

cards.definition: A payment made to sales reps in advance of earned commissions, which may be recoverable or non-recoverable.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides income stability during ramp or slow periods; critical for cash flow management.
cards.howItWorks: Draw paid each period → Commission earned offsets draw → Excess commission paid → Deficit may carry forward.
cards.example: Monthly draw $8K. Rep earns $5K commission → Keeps $8K draw, $3K deficit. Next month earns $12K → Pays back $3K, keeps $9K.

cards.definition: A draw that must be repaid from future commission earnings, creating a debt balance when commissions are below draw amount.
cards.whyItMatters: Balances rep income stability with company cost control; creates debt obligation.
cards.howItWorks: Draw paid → Commissions earned → If commission < draw, deficit accumulates → If commission > draw, deficit repaid first.
cards.example: 3-month ramp with $10K/month recoverable draw. After ramp, $30K deficit. Rep earns $15K/month, $5K repays deficit over 6 months.

cards.definition: A guaranteed minimum payment that does not need to be repaid if commissions fall short.
cards.whyItMatters: Strongest form of income protection; typically used for new hires or territory transitions.
cards.howItWorks: Guarantee paid each period → If commission exceeds guarantee, excess paid → If commission below, no repayment required.
cards.example: 6-month guarantee at $15K/month. Rep earns $8K in month 3 → Keeps $15K, no debt. Month 5 earns $20K → Gets $20K.

cards.definition: A reconciliation process to adjust commission payments to reflect actual performance, typically done at period end.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures accurate final payments when estimates were used during the period.
cards.howItWorks: Monthly estimates paid → Quarter-end actuals calculated → Difference paid (positive true-up) or deducted (negative true-up).
cards.example: Monthly estimates totaled $45K. Actual quarterly commission $50K. True-up payment of $5K issued.

cards.definition: When sales credit for a single transaction is divided among multiple participants.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables team selling while controlling total credit/cost; complex to administer.
cards.howItWorks: Deal credit allocated per rules → Splits may be fixed (50/50) or variable → Each party gets portion toward quota.
cards.example: Enterprise AE and Partner Manager split $500K deal 60/40. AE gets $300K credit, PM gets $200K credit.

cards.definition: When multiple participants each receive full (100%) credit for the same transaction.
cards.whyItMatters: Maximizes incentive alignment but increases cost; used strategically for priority initiatives.
cards.howItWorks: Deal closes → Each eligible party receives 100% credit → Total credit exceeds deal value → Higher cost of sales.
cards.example: New product launch: AE gets 100% credit, Product Specialist gets 100% credit. $100K deal = $200K total credit.

cards.definition: Requirements under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act for internal controls over financial reporting, including commission accruals.
cards.whyItMatters: Commission accruals are material financial items requiring documented controls and audit trails.
cards.howItWorks: Document controls → Implement segregation of duties → Maintain audit trails → Test effectiveness → External audit review.
cards.example: Plan document approval requires VP Sales + Finance sign-off. Commission calculations reviewed by separate analyst. Changes logged.

cards.definition: A control principle ensuring no single person has authority over all aspects of a financial transaction.
cards.whyItMatters: Prevents fraud and errors by requiring multiple parties for sensitive operations.
cards.howItWorks: Identify conflicting duties → Separate to different roles → If separation impossible, implement compensating controls.
cards.example: Plan design (Sales Ops) separate from calculation (Comp Admin) separate from payment approval (Finance).

cards.definition: A complete, chronological record of all changes and transactions in the compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: Required for SOX compliance, dispute resolution, and forensic analysis.
cards.howItWorks: System logs all changes → Who, what, when, why captured → Logs immutable → Retention per policy (typically 7 years).
cards.example: Quota change logged: 'User: JSmith, Date: 2026-01-15, Field: Q1_Quota, Old: $1M, New: $1.2M, Reason: Territory expansion'.

cards.definition: IRS regulations governing deferred compensation, applicable to certain commission payment structures.
cards.whyItMatters: Non-compliance results in 20% penalty tax plus interest on the employee; company may face penalties too.
cards.howItWorks: Identify deferral arrangements → Ensure compliant timing/triggers → Document elections → Report properly.
cards.example: Commission payment >2.5 months after year-end may trigger 409A. Must either pay sooner or structure as compliant deferral.

cards.definition: A policy allowing the company to recover previously paid commissions under specified circumstances.
cards.whyItMatters: Protects against overpayments from cancellations, fraud, or calculation errors.
cards.howItWorks: Define triggering events → Specify recovery window → Document recovery method → Communicate to reps → Enforce consistently.
cards.example: Deal cancels within 90 days: Full clawback. Months 91-180: 50% clawback. After 180 days: No clawback.

cards.definition: The process for requesting, approving, and documenting deviations from standard compensation policies.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables flexibility while maintaining control and consistency.
cards.howItWorks: Request submitted → Appropriate approvals obtained → Exception documented → Time-limited → Reviewed for patterns.
cards.example: AE requests quota relief for medical leave. Requires Sales VP + HR approval. Relief granted for 60 days with documentation.

cards.definition: The formal process for reps to challenge compensation calculations or policy interpretations.
cards.whyItMatters: Fair disputes process builds trust and identifies systemic issues.
cards.howItWorks: Rep submits dispute → Initial review by comp admin → Escalation if needed → Decision documented → Adjustment if warranted.
cards.example: Rep disputes missing credit. Admin reviews, finds data lag issue. Credit added, process improved, rep notified.

cards.definition: A policy addressing unusually large commission payouts that result from atypical deals or circumstances.
cards.whyItMatters: Manages cost risk from outlier deals while maintaining fairness.
cards.howItWorks: Define windfall threshold → Trigger review process → May cap, spread, or adjust payment → Document rationale.
cards.example: Deal >5x average triggers windfall review. $5M deal earns $500K commission but capped at 3x target ($300K) with remainder deferred.

cards.definition: An AI-driven score predicting the likelihood of a desired outcome (conversion, upsell, churn).
cards.whyItMatters: Enables prioritization of opportunities and resources based on predicted outcomes.
cards.howItWorks: Historical data fed to ML model → Model identifies patterns → Scores generated for current accounts → Scores updated continuously.
cards.example: Account X: Propensity to buy = 78%, Propensity to churn = 12%. Prioritize for upsell over retention intervention.

cards.definition: An AI-generated score predicting the likelihood that an open opportunity will close.
cards.whyItMatters: Improves forecast accuracy and helps reps focus on winnable deals.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze deal attributes → Compare to historical patterns → Generate probability score → Update as deal progresses.
cards.example: Opportunity: Strong champion (80), no budget confirmed (60), competitor involved (40). Composite score: 62% win probability.

cards.definition: Analysis of sales pipeline to assess health, velocity, and forecast reliability.
cards.whyItMatters: Early warning system for revenue shortfalls and coaching opportunities.
cards.howItWorks: Measure pipeline coverage → Analyze stage conversion rates → Track velocity metrics → Identify bottlenecks.
cards.example: Pipeline coverage 2.8x vs. 3.5x target. Stage 2→3 conversion dropped 15%. Focus on qualification rigor.

cards.definition: Comparing performance of groups (cohorts) defined by shared characteristics, typically time-based.
cards.whyItMatters: Reveals trends and enables fair comparison by controlling for external factors.
cards.howItWorks: Define cohort criteria → Group entities → Track same metrics over time → Compare cohorts.
cards.example: Q1 2026 new hires vs. Q1 2025: Compare ramp to first deal, time to quota, retention at 12 months.

cards.definition: A ranked display of sales rep performance, often used to drive competition and recognition.
cards.whyItMatters: Motivates through competition and visibility; highlights top performers.
cards.howItWorks: Define ranking metric → Calculate rankings → Display dynamically → Update regularly.
cards.example: Monthly attainment leaderboard: 1. Jones 142%, 2. Smith 128%, 3. Chen 124%. Top 10 highlighted, updates daily.

cards.definition: Software for calculating, managing, and reporting sales compensation and commissions.
cards.whyItMatters: Automates complex calculations, ensures accuracy, provides visibility.
cards.howItWorks: Ingest transaction data → Apply plan rules → Calculate commissions → Generate statements → Process payments.
cards.example: Xactly, Varicent, CaptivateIQ, Forma.ai, Spiff, Performio, Anaplan.

cards.definition: The core component that applies plan rules to transaction data to compute commissions.
cards.whyItMatters: Must handle complex rules with speed and accuracy at scale.
cards.howItWorks: Load transactions → Match to reps → Apply crediting rules → Calculate rates → Apply modifiers → Store results.
cards.example: Engine processes 500K transactions/day, applies 200 distinct plan variations, calculates in under 30 minutes.

cards.definition: The process and technology for moving data between SPM systems and other enterprise applications.
cards.whyItMatters: Accurate compensation requires accurate, timely data from multiple sources.
cards.howItWorks: Extract from source → Transform/cleanse → Load to target → Validate → Reconcile.
cards.example: CRM (opportunities) → ICM (calculations) → ERP (payments) → Payroll (disbursement). Daily batch + real-time events.

cards.definition: A self-service interface where sales reps view their compensation details and performance.
cards.whyItMatters: Transparency reduces disputes and increases trust in compensation.
cards.howItWorks: Rep logs in → Views earnings by period → Drills into transaction details → Submits inquiries if needed.
cards.example: Monthly statement shows: Total earnings, YTD attainment, transaction list, calculation breakdown, inquiry button.

cards.definition: A company's guiding principles for how it approaches compensation, including market positioning and pay-for-performance beliefs.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides foundation for consistent, defensible compensation decisions.
cards.howItWorks: Define principles → Document philosophy → Align all plans → Communicate to organization.
cards.example: Philosophy: Target 75th percentile for top performers. Pay mix 50/50 for AEs. No caps to reward unlimited upside.

cards.definition: The ratio of base salary to variable (at-risk) compensation in total target compensation.
cards.whyItMatters: Signals risk/reward balance and attracts appropriate talent profile.
cards.howItWorks: Higher variable = more aggressive, attracts risk-takers. Higher fixed = more conservative, attracts stability-seekers.
cards.example: Inside Sales: 70/30 (lower risk). Enterprise AE: 50/50 (balanced). BDR: 60/40 (moderate). Pure commission: 0/100.

cards.definition: The relationship between performance above target and earnings above target incentive.
cards.whyItMatters: High leverage drives aggressive behavior; low leverage provides stability.
cards.howItWorks: 1x leverage: 120% attainment = 120% payout. 2x leverage: 120% attainment = 140% payout.
cards.example: Target incentive $100K with 2x leverage above 100%. At 150% attainment: $100K + ($50K × 2) = $200K earnings.

cards.definition: The total expected earnings (base + variable) when a sales rep achieves 100% of quota.
cards.whyItMatters: Primary recruiting metric; basis for market benchmarking and internal equity.
cards.howItWorks: OTE = Base Salary + Target Incentive. Represents expected earnings at plan performance.
cards.example: Enterprise AE OTE $280K: $140K base (50%) + $140K target incentive (50%) at 100% attainment.

cards.definition: Application of psychological principles to understand how compensation design influences sales behavior.
cards.whyItMatters: Better plan design when you understand human decision-making biases.
cards.howItWorks: Identify desired behaviors → Understand psychological drivers → Design plan elements to leverage.
cards.example: Loss aversion: Use floors not just accelerators. Goal gradient: Increase rates near quota. Present bias: Frequent payouts.

cards.definition: Initial project phase to understand current state, gather requirements, and define project scope.
cards.whyItMatters: Thorough discovery prevents costly rework and scope creep later.
cards.howItWorks: Stakeholder interviews → Current state documentation → Requirements gathering → Gap analysis → Scope definition.
cards.example: 4-week discovery: Interview 20 stakeholders, document 15 plan types, identify 50 requirements, define MVP scope.

cards.definition: Running new and old systems simultaneously to validate calculation accuracy before go-live.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical risk mitigation; ensures accuracy before affecting real payments.
cards.howItWorks: Process same data through both systems → Compare results → Investigate variances → Achieve target match rate.
cards.example: 3-month parallel: Month 1 at 92% match, Month 2 at 98%, Month 3 at 99.5%. Go-live approved at >99%.

cards.definition: The structured approach to transitioning individuals and organizations to a new compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: Technology success depends on user adoption; change management drives adoption.
cards.howItWorks: Stakeholder analysis → Communication plan → Training program → Go-live support → Reinforcement.
cards.example: OCM plan: Executive sponsor communications (monthly), manager training (2 hours), rep training (1 hour), go-live war room.

cards.definition: Intensive support period immediately following system go-live to resolve issues quickly.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical period for user confidence; fast issue resolution prevents loss of trust.
cards.howItWorks: Dedicated support team → Rapid issue triage → Daily status calls → Extended hours → Gradual reduction.
cards.example: 4-week hypercare: Week 1-2 daily calls, 24/7 support. Week 3-4 reduce to daily email, business hours.

cards.definition: State-specific laws governing when and how commissions must be paid, often more restrictive than federal law.
cards.whyItMatters: Non-compliance exposes company to significant penalties and lawsuits.
cards.howItWorks: Identify applicable states → Understand specific requirements → Design compliant processes → Monitor for changes.
cards.example: California: Written commission agreement required, commissions due on determinable date, no clawback of earned commissions.

cards.definition: California law requiring written commission agreements that specify computation method, payment timing, and terms.
cards.whyItMatters: California has strictest commission laws; violations create significant liability.
cards.howItWorks: Provide written plan → Get signed acknowledgment → Pay when determinable → No post-termination clawbacks of earned commissions.
cards.example: CA AE must have signed commission agreement. If deal closes, commission is earned. Cannot claw back after termination.

cards.definition: Federal law governing minimum wage and overtime, with specific exemptions for certain commissioned sales employees.
cards.whyItMatters: Misclassification of exempt status creates significant back-pay liability.
cards.howItWorks: Test for exemption → If exempt, no overtime required → If non-exempt, track hours, pay overtime on commissions.
cards.example: Outside sales exemption: Customarily works away from employer's place of business making sales. No overtime required.

cards.definition: EU regulation governing personal data processing, applicable to compensation data for EU employees.
cards.whyItMatters: Compensation data is personal data; violations can result in significant fines.
cards.howItWorks: Identify personal data → Establish legal basis → Implement safeguards → Enable data subject rights → Document compliance.
cards.example: EU sales rep compensation data: Legal basis (employment contract), data minimization, retention limits, access on request.

cards.definition: Country-specific regulations governing sales commission structures, many more prescriptive than US.
cards.whyItMatters: Same plan design may be illegal in different countries; requires local expertise.
cards.howItWorks: Identify operating countries → Research local requirements → Design compliant plans → Get local legal review.
cards.example: France: Variable pay typically capped at 10-30% of total. Germany: Works council consultation required. UK: Written particulars needed.

cards.definition: Analysis of the total revenue opportunity available if 100% market share were achieved.
cards.whyItMatters: Anchors territory sizing and quota allocation to objective market data.
cards.howItWorks: Define market scope → Identify all potential buyers → Estimate spend per buyer → Sum total opportunity.
cards.example: Enterprise software TAM: 500 companies × $500K average deal size = $250M total market.

cards.definition: The portion of TAM that your product and go-to-market can realistically target.
cards.whyItMatters: More realistic basis for capacity planning than total market.
cards.howItWorks: Start with TAM → Filter for product fit → Filter for go-to-market reach → Remaining = SAM.
cards.example: TAM $250M, but we only sell to Fortune 1000. SAM = 200 accounts × $500K = $100M serviceable.

cards.definition: The portion of SAM that you can realistically capture given current resources and competition.
cards.whyItMatters: Most relevant for annual planning and quota setting.
cards.howItWorks: Start with SAM → Apply win rate assumptions → Factor capacity constraints → Result = SOM.
cards.example: SAM $100M, 25% win rate assumption, 50 reps × $1.5M quota capacity = SOM $50M.

cards.definition: A detailed description of the type of company that is the ideal customer for your product.
cards.whyItMatters: Focuses sales effort on highest-probability opportunities.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze best customers → Identify common attributes → Document profile → Use for targeting and scoring.
cards.example: ICP: B2B SaaS, 200-2000 employees, Series B+, North America, using Salesforce, growing >30% YoY.

cards.definition: A short-term incentive program layered on top of base commission plans to drive specific behaviors.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables rapid response to business priorities without changing core plans.
cards.howItWorks: Define objective → Set rules and period → Communicate → Track → Pay promptly.
cards.example: Q4 SPIF: $500 bonus per new logo closed. Two-week product launch SPIF: 2x commission on new product.

cards.definition: A bonus component based on achievement of predefined qualitative or quantitative objectives.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables compensation for important activities not captured in revenue metrics.
cards.howItWorks: Define objectives at period start → Weight by importance → Assess achievement → Calculate payout.
cards.example: Manager MBO: 30% on team attainment, 30% on retention, 20% on forecast accuracy, 20% on training completion.

cards.definition: Ranking all sales reps against each other, sometimes forcing distribution into performance categories.
cards.whyItMatters: Controversial but used to identify top and bottom performers for rewards/actions.
cards.howItWorks: Rank all reps by metric → Apply forced distribution (optional) → Use for PIP, promotion, bonus allocation.
cards.example: Top 20%: High performer bonus. Middle 60%: Standard treatment. Bottom 20%: Performance improvement plan.

cards.definition: A cross-functional committee responsible for compensation governance, policy decisions, and exception approvals.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides formal governance structure for compensation decisions.
cards.howItWorks: Regular meetings → Review exception requests → Make policy decisions → Document and communicate.
cards.example: Monthly SGCC: VP Sales, VP Finance, Legal, HR. Reviews 5-10 exceptions, approves plan changes, addresses disputes.

cards.definition: The formal written document specifying all terms and conditions of a sales compensation plan.
cards.whyItMatters: Legal requirement in many states; defines rights and obligations.
cards.howItWorks: Draft plan terms → Legal review → Publish to reps → Obtain acknowledgment → Retain records.
cards.example: 2026 Enterprise AE Plan: 10 pages covering quota, rates, crediting, payment timing, clawback, dispute process.

cards.definition: A metric measuring the speed at which revenue moves through the sales pipeline.
cards.whyItMatters: Comprehensive health metric combining multiple pipeline factors.
cards.howItWorks: Velocity = (# Opportunities × Win Rate × Average Deal Size) ÷ Sales Cycle Length
cards.example: 100 opps × 25% win rate × $50K ADS ÷ 90 days = $1.39M monthly velocity.

cards.definition: The percentage of opportunities that result in closed-won deals.
cards.whyItMatters: Key indicator of sales effectiveness and forecast accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: Win Rate = Closed Won ÷ (Closed Won + Closed Lost). Excludes open opportunities.
cards.example: Q4: 50 closed won, 150 closed lost. Win rate = 50/200 = 25%.

cards.definition: The measure of how closely sales forecasts match actual results.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical for business planning, resource allocation, and investor confidence.
cards.howItWorks: Accuracy = 1 - |Forecast - Actual| ÷ Actual. Track by rep, team, and time horizon.
cards.example: Week 1 forecast: $2M. Actual: $1.8M. Accuracy = 1 - 0.2/1.8 = 89%.

cards.definition: The ability to model different plan designs or performance scenarios to project outcomes.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables data-driven plan design decisions before implementation.
cards.howItWorks: Define scenario parameters → Run calculation engine → Compare results → Iterate.
cards.example: Model: If we add 10% accelerator above 100%, projected cost increases $2M with 15% performance lift.

cards.definition: The process of tracking commission liabilities for financial reporting, often before actual payment.
cards.whyItMatters: Required for accurate financial statements and SOX compliance.
cards.howItWorks: Calculate earned commissions → Accrue liability → Reconcile to payments → Adjust accruals.
cards.example: December close: Accrue $5M in earned commissions payable in January. Reconcile when paid.

cards.definition: Comparing compensation plans and levels to market data from similar companies and roles.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures competitive positioning to attract and retain talent.
cards.howItWorks: Identify peer group → Collect market data → Match roles → Analyze positioning → Adjust if needed.
cards.example: Benchmark Enterprise AE OTE against Series C+ B2B SaaS in SF Bay Area. Current $250K vs. market 50th percentile $275K.

cards.definition: The ratio of total sales compensation cost to revenue generated.
cards.whyItMatters: Key metric for evaluating sales efficiency and plan affordability.
cards.howItWorks: Cost of Sales = Total Sales Comp ÷ Total Revenue. Track by segment, role, tenure.
cards.example: Enterprise segment: $20M comp for $100M revenue = 20% cost of sales.

cards.definition: Testing phase where business users validate system functionality meets requirements.
cards.whyItMatters: Last line of defense before go-live; catches issues missed in technical testing.
cards.howItWorks: Develop test cases → Train testers → Execute tests → Log defects → Retest → Sign off.
cards.example: 4-week UAT: 100 test cases covering plan rules, edge cases, integrations. 15 defects found, all resolved.

cards.definition: The process of moving data from legacy systems to the new compensation platform.
cards.whyItMatters: Historical data critical for continuity, reporting, and validation.
cards.howItWorks: Extract legacy data → Transform to new format → Load to new system → Validate → Reconcile.
cards.example: Migrate 3 years of transaction history, plan documents, and quota assignments from spreadsheets to ICM platform.

cards.definition: New York law requiring written commission agreements for sales reps.
cards.whyItMatters: Non-compliance enables rep to recover full commission as wages owed.
cards.howItWorks: Provide written terms before employment starts → Include calculation method, payment timing → Get acknowledgment.
cards.example: NY AE employment offer must include commission plan attachment with all material terms before start date.

cards.definition: Illinois law governing commission payments with specific timing and documentation requirements.
cards.whyItMatters: Violations can result in 2% penalty per month plus attorney fees.
cards.howItWorks: Written agreement required → Pay within 13 days of month end or agreed schedule → Final pay within statutory period.
cards.example: IL reps must receive commissions within 13 days of month end, or per written agreement terms.

cards.definition: The process of removing accounts or geographic regions from one territory and assigning to another.
cards.whyItMatters: Common but contentious; requires clear policy and fair treatment.
cards.howItWorks: Identify accounts for move → Calculate quota impact → Adjust quotas → Communicate → Update systems.
cards.example: New Enterprise AE hired for healthcare vertical. 50 healthcare accounts carved from existing territories, quotas adjusted.

cards.definition: A coverage model where specific high-value accounts are explicitly assigned to individual reps.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures dedicated focus on most important accounts.
cards.howItWorks: Identify strategic accounts → Assign to specific reps → Define ownership rules → Track relationship depth.
cards.example: Top 200 enterprise accounts named to 50 Strategic AEs. Each AE owns 4 accounts with full relationship responsibility.

cards.definition: A detailed report showing a sales rep their compensation calculations for a given period.
cards.whyItMatters: Transparency builds trust and reduces disputes.
cards.howItWorks: Show total earnings → Break down by component → List transactions → Show YTD progress → Provide drill-down.
cards.example: Monthly statement: Base $10K, Commission $15K (list of 5 deals with rates), SPIF $2K, YTD attainment 85%.

cards.definition: The degree to which reps can see and understand how their compensation is calculated.
cards.whyItMatters: High transparency reduces disputes and increases motivation.
cards.howItWorks: Show inputs (transactions, rates, quotas) → Show calculation steps → Show outputs → Enable verification.
cards.example: Deal XYZ: $100K × 5% base rate × 1.2 accelerator (above quota) = $6,000 commission. Rep can verify each element.

cards.definition: A governance body for adjudicating compensation disputes that cannot be resolved at lower levels.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides formal escalation path and consistent decision-making.
cards.howItWorks: Dispute submitted → Initial review fails → Escalated to CRB → Evidence reviewed → Decision rendered → Communicated.
cards.example: CRB meets monthly. Reviews 3-5 escalated disputes. Members: VP Sales, VP Legal, VP HR. Decisions are final.

cards.definition: The formal process for proposing, approving, and implementing changes to compensation plans or systems.
cards.whyItMatters: Prevents unauthorized changes and ensures proper documentation.
cards.howItWorks: Request submitted → Impact assessed → Approvals obtained → Change implemented → Verified → Communicated.
cards.example: Accelerator change request: Submit business case, Finance models cost, Legal reviews, VP Sales approves, Comp Admin implements.

cards.definition: A composite score based on sales activities (calls, emails, meetings) that correlates with outcomes.
cards.whyItMatters: Leading indicator of deal health and rep effectiveness.
cards.howItWorks: Track activities by type → Weight by importance → Calculate score → Compare to benchmarks → Alert on issues.
cards.example: Deal Activity Score: 15 emails (10pts), 3 calls (15pts), 2 meetings (20pts), proposal sent (15pts) = 60/100.

cards.definition: AI-powered platforms that analyze sales conversations and data to provide insights and recommendations.
cards.whyItMatters: Transforms unstructured sales data into actionable intelligence.
cards.howItWorks: Capture conversations → Transcribe and analyze → Identify patterns → Surface insights → Recommend actions.
cards.example: Gong, Chorus, Clari analyze call recordings to identify winning behaviors, competitive mentions, and deal risks.

cards.definition: Using application programming interfaces to connect SPM systems with other enterprise applications.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables real-time data flow and reduces manual data handling.
cards.howItWorks: Define data requirements → Map API endpoints → Build connections → Test → Monitor → Maintain.
cards.example: Salesforce API pushes closed-won opportunities to ICM in real-time. ICM API returns commission calculations to Salesforce.

cards.definition: The process of ensuring consistent, accurate master data (reps, accounts, products) across systems.
cards.whyItMatters: Commission accuracy depends on correct master data; inconsistencies cause errors.
cards.howItWorks: Define golden source → Establish sync rules → Monitor for drift → Resolve conflicts → Audit regularly.
cards.example: HRIS is golden source for rep data. Sync to CRM and ICM daily. Flag mismatches for resolution.

cards.definition: The behavioral economics principle that losses feel more painful than equivalent gains feel good.
cards.whyItMatters: Can be leveraged in plan design to increase motivation.
cards.howItWorks: People work harder to avoid losing $100 than to gain $100. Use in threshold design, clawback framing.
cards.example: Frame decelerator as 'earn 100% rate by reaching floor' rather than 'lose commission below floor'.

cards.definition: The behavioral principle that effort increases as people get closer to their goal.
cards.whyItMatters: Inform threshold and accelerator placement for maximum motivation.
cards.howItWorks: Reps at 90% quota work harder than at 50%. Place accelerators just above typical attainment.
cards.example: Accelerator kicks in at 95% instead of 100%. Rep at 92% pushes hard to reach accelerator zone.

cards.definition: A structured learning program for users of the new compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: User adoption depends on understanding how to use the system effectively.
cards.howItWorks: Identify user groups → Define learning objectives → Develop content → Deliver training → Assess competency.
cards.example: Rep training: 30-min self-service module. Manager training: 1-hour live session. Admin training: 2-day certification.

cards.definition: A formal assessment of whether all prerequisites are met to launch the new system.
cards.whyItMatters: Structured checkpoint prevents launching before ready.
cards.howItWorks: Define readiness criteria → Assess status → Address gaps → Get sign-off → Proceed to go-live.
cards.example: Readiness checklist: UAT complete ✓, Parallel passed ✓, Training done ✓, Data migrated ✓, Support ready ✓. Go-live approved.

cards.definition: A legally binding document between employer and sales rep defining commission terms.
cards.whyItMatters: Required by law in many states; protects both parties.
cards.howItWorks: Draft terms → Legal review → Present to rep → Obtain signature → Retain copy → Update annually.
cards.example: Agreement includes: Effective dates, quota, rates, payment timing, clawback terms, dispute process, termination provisions.

cards.definition: Commission payments owed to a terminated sales rep, subject to state-specific rules.
cards.whyItMatters: States vary significantly; errors create legal exposure.
cards.howItWorks: Determine applicable state law → Calculate earned commissions → Pay within required timeframe → Document.
cards.example: California: Pay all earned commissions immediately upon involuntary termination. Pending deals may still earn if close within X days.

cards.definition: Employee representative bodies in certain countries that must be consulted on compensation changes.
cards.whyItMatters: Failure to consult can invalidate compensation changes.
cards.howItWorks: Inform council of planned changes → Provide required information → Consult/negotiate → Obtain agreement or proceed per law.
cards.example: Germany: Works council must be consulted on pay structure changes. France: Works council must be informed of bonus schemes.
